meaning_mnemonic:
When you <kanji>calculate</kanji> and <kanji>determine</kanji> (the calculation), you are determining the calculation. That's why this word is <vocabulary>to calculate</vocabulary>.

Unlike 計算する, which means “to calculate” in general, 算定する is a formal word that focuses more on the final value of a calculation, instead of the process of calculating itself.

The prime minister's (総理) <kanji>government</kanji> is where he does all his governmenting. It's where the Japanese <vocabulary>Prime Minister's Office</vocabulary> (aka the <vocabulary>Cabinet Office</vocabulary>) is located as well.

総理府 was actually renamed 内閣府 in 2001, so you'd generally only use 総理府 to talk about the Cabinet Offices from back in the day.
A <kanji>sand</kanji> <kanji>desert</kanji> is just a <vocabulary>desert</vocabulary>.

Something with a <kanji>vague</kanji> <kanji>nature</kanji> is also quite <vocabulary>vague</vocabulary>. 

Note that you need to add と to the end of this word to make it an adverb, and たる to make it an adjective!

Remember how 傷 is "wound"? Now a wound is つくing to you, or in other words, is getting attached to you. If you get a wound attached to your body, you are probably going <vocabulary>to get hurt</vocabulary>.

You have <kanji>one</kanji> <kanji>muscle</kanji>, therefore it only does one thing. That's it. It is <vocabulary>single mindedly</vocabulary> doing that one thing. It is <vocabulary>intently</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>earnestly</vocabulary> doing that one thing.
If 宣言 is a "proclamation," then the verb version will be <vocabulary>to proclaim</vocabulary>.

盛る is "to heap up." If you "raise" (上げる) what you heap up, well, that comes with heaping something up, making this word <vocabulary>to heap up</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to pile up</vocabulary>. This word is also used when you want <vocabulary>to liven up</vocabulary> some things. Heap up that energy and stir things up!
<kanji>Someone</kanji> who backstabs (裏切り) someone is a <vocabulary>traitor</vocabulary>.
You have <kanji>various</kanji> <kanji>various</kanji> things. They are <vocabulary>various</vocabulary>. You have <vocabulary>all kinds of</vocabulary> them.
編む is "to knit." When you knit in <kanji>three</kanji>s, you are knitting in a braid style. What do you braid? Hair. That makes this <vocabulary>braided hair</vocabulary>.

If 納める is "to supply" or "to deliver," then this word is when things have been delivered: so it's <vocabulary>to settle into</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be satisfied</vocabulary>. 

納まる means something or someone has found its right place and settled there. It often implies that there was a prior state of uncertainty or dissatisfaction, but now everything is in its right place.

Like most verbs with まる as okurigana, this is an intransitive verb. That means it happens by itself, with no emphasis on the person or thing that's making something settle or be satisfied.

I will <kanji>supply</kanji> and you will <kanji>acquire</kanji>. Does that sound good? Do I have your <vocabulary>consent</vocabulary>? I can see that you're <vocabulary>understanding</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>being convinced</vocabulary>. You're planning on <vocabulary>accepting</vocabulary> my proposition, aren't you?

否定 is denial. Remember how 形 sometimes refers to grammar tense / type? Well, with a denial type grammar, you have a <vocabulary>negative form</vocabulary>, making it a <vocabulary>negative sentence</vocabulary>.
If 否定 is "denial," then the verb version would be <vocabulary>to deny</vocabulary>.
If 尊敬 is "respect" then the verb version would be <vocabulary>to respect</vocabulary>.
尊敬 is respect. A respect <kanji>language</kanji> is <vocabulary>honorific Japanese</vocabulary> (or <vocabulary>honorific language</vocabulary>, though usually this refers to Japanese).
If 暮らす is "to live" or "to live one's life" then the noun version would be simply <vocabulary>life</vocabulary>.

You have the <kanji>same</kanji> <kanji>sound</kanji> with a <vocabulary>different meaning</vocabulary> (異義), and it's a part of <kanji>language</kanji>. Same sounds... different meanings... that sounds like a <vocabulary>homophone</vocabulary>, or a <vocabulary>homonym</vocabulary>.

著作 is "writing" or "authorship." The <kanji>rights</kanji> that writing has is what's known as <vocabulary>copyright</vocabulary>.

Note that 著作権 refers to copyright for anything, not just writing.

If it’s a <kanji>steam</kanji>ing <kanji>hot</kanji> day, it means the weather is <vocabulary>hot and humid</vocabulary> (or you can just say <vocabulary>humid</vocabulary>, because that usually implies hotness too). This is a useful word for summers in Japan, since you'll complain about this all the time.

You <kanji>steam</kanji> something to <kanji>return</kanji> it to its previously warm state. This is when you go <vocabulary>to reheat</vocabulary> something. But we usually use it to talk about bringing something up again and again in conversations or arguments. That's why it means <vocabulary>to rehash</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to bring up again</vocabulary>. You're bringing up memories from the past and steaming them up again.

If you go to <kanji>attire</kanji> yourself, you're covering up who you are and trying to be someone else. You are trying <vocabulary>to feign</vocabulary>. You are trying <vocabulary>to wear</vocabulary> a lie. You are trying <vocabulary>to pretend</vocabulary>.
If something or someone is <kanji>slow</kanji>, and they "do slow" they are going <vocabulary>to be late</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>slow</kanji> <kanji>carve</kanji> is so slow. If you carve something slowly, it will take you a long time. You will <vocabulary>be late</vocabulary> with a slow carve like that.
I was too <kanji>slow</kanji>, so we'll have to <kanji>prolong</kanji> the time in which this product will come out. This is a <vocabulary>delay</vocabulary> :(
You <kanji>carve</kanji> then you <kanji>carve</kanji> again. So much carving until, wait, wow, it looks like something! All that carving became a <vocabulary>sculpture</vocabulary>!

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>measure</kanji> so the verb vocab means <vocabulary>to measure</vocabulary>. This word generally has to do with scientific or medical measurements.

When you <kanji>infer</kanji> and <kanji>measure</kanji>, it’ll lead to some sort of <vocabulary>conjecture</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>speculation</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>guess</vocabulary> about something.

推測 means guessing based on known facts or information, while using reasoning to fill in the gaps.

A beforehand measure is when you make a prediction or estimation about something. While 予想 often refers to a subjective prediction, 予測 generally refers to forecasting future events based on objective evidence.
<kanji>View</kanji> and <kanji>measure</kanji> what you are watching. This is <vocabulary>observation</vocabulary>. It is no mere viewing, it is more than that.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>tear</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to tear</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Tear</kanji> and <kanji>break</kanji> everything, taking it all down. <vocabulary>Destruction</vocabulary>! <vocabulary>Demolition</vocabulary>!
A <kanji>tear</kanji> in your <kanji>ship</kanji> will cause it to wreck, making it a <vocabulary>shipwreck</vocabulary>.

If someone <kanji>tear</kanji>s all your <kanji>property</kanji> it'll lead to <vocabulary>bankruptcy</vocabulary>. With all your property torn, you're going to <vocabulary>go bankrupt</vocabulary>. What mean person did that?

A <kanji>rice paddy</kanji> and a <kanji>cottage</kanji>. This is the image of the <vocabulary>countryside</vocabulary> to me. This is <vocabulary>rural</vocabulary>. Just cottages and rice paddies...
A <kanji>soldier</kanji> <kanji>cottage</kanji> is a place where the soldiers stay. This is the <vocabulary>barracks</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>government office</kanji> <kanji>cottage</kanji> is the place where the government office is stored. That's the <vocabulary>government office building</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Perform</kanji> your <kanji>lecture</kanji>. This is your <vocabulary>lecture</vocabulary>. This is your <vocabulary>address</vocabulary> to the people.
A <kanji>lecture</kanji> <kanji>expert</kanji> is a <vocabulary>lecturer</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>instructor</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Lecture</kanji> of <kanji>righteousness</kanji> is still a <vocabulary>lecture</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>stagnate</kanji>, and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to be overdue</vocabulary>. After all, if something stagnates, it's not advancing, which causes it <vocabulary>to be delayed</vocabulary>.
I am too <kanji>slow</kanji> so things have really begun to <kanji>stagnate</kanji>. What a <vocabulary>delay</vocabulary>.
My <kanji>introduce</kanji> was <kanji>jammed in</kanji> there for you to hear. That is my <vocabulary>introduction</vocabulary>. Jammin' it in.

I <kanji>jammed in</kanji> myself and <kanji>enter</kanji>ed your personal life. Because I care, you know? I don't want you to be addicted to My Little Pony anymore, so this is an <vocabulary>intervention</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. It also means <vocabulary>myself</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>I</vocabulary>.
Your <kanji>self</kanji> <kanji>oneself</kanji>, is your <vocabulary>oneself</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>self</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>misfortune</kanji> is just getting <kanji>jammed in</kanji> there. So much misfortune leads to very <vocabulary>troublesome</vocabulary> <vocabulary>trouble</vocabulary>.

厄介 describes something or someone that is troublesome, or the trouble itself. It's very similar to 面倒, but 厄介 is often used for more challenging or complicated situations.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. BURN BURN BURN.
A <kanji>sea</kanji> <kanji>turtle</kanji> is a <vocabulary>sea turtle</vocabulary>. Cowabunga!

Despite it looking like an adjective, this is the noun version of the kanji, making it <vocabulary>mutual</vocabulary>. It also means <vocabulary>each other</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>reciprocal</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>together</vocabulary>, too.
<kanji>Mutual</kanji> and <kanji>mutual</kanji> is <vocabulary>mutual</vocabulary>.
You <kanji>mix</kanji>, then you go <kanji>mutual</kanji>, then you mix, and then you go mutual. <vocabulary>Alternately</vocabulary>, you could go mix again?

The <kanji>reality</kanji> of the <kanji>sword</kanji> is that it will cut you right in half and kill you, easily. The fact that this is true is a very <vocabulary>serious</vocabulary> thing. Very serious.
The <kanji>path</kanji> of the <kanji>sword</kanji> is known as <vocabulary>kendo</vocabulary>. You could also say <vocabulary>Japanese fencing</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>lifespan</kanji> of a <kanji>director</kanji> depends on how much <vocabulary>sushi</vocabulary> they eat. 

Okay, the kanji in 寿司 aren't actually related to the meaning of the word, so this one's kind of tricky. Just try to think of sushi as the secret to a long lifespan for directors. Imagine all those directors wolfing down a bunch of sushi because they're desperate to lengthen their lifespans.
Your <kanji>lifespan</kanji> is your <kanji>fate</kanji> and will show you how long your <vocabulary>lifespan</vocabulary> is.
A <kanji>long</kanji> <kanji>lifespan</kanji> is a <vocabulary>long life</vocabulary>.

You can <kanji>rejoice</kanji> because your <kanji>lifespan</kanji> has reached this special point. That special point is your <vocabulary>seventy seventh birthday</vocabulary>. So many sevens, lucky!
<kanji>Luck</kanji> for your whole <kanji>lifespan</kanji>, that's a life of <vocabulary>happiness and longevity</vocabulary>.

This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>shame</kanji>? It could be <vocabulary>ashamed</vocabulary> or even <vocabulary> embarrassing</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
<kanji>Fruit</kanji> <kanji>soup</kanji> isn't really a soup, it's more of a <vocabulary>fruit juice</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

A <kanji>flavor</kanji> that makes foods <kanji>boisterous</kanji> is a great flavor. In this case, it's the flavor of <vocabulary>miso</vocabulary>, which goes in a lot of Japanese dishes, and certainly does make the flavor of things boisterous.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same!
When you have <kanji>flame</kanji> <kanji>symptom</kanji>s that's when you feel like you're filled with fire, which is <vocabulary> inflammation</vocabulary>.

You move towards the <kanji>sake</kanji>. When you move towards it, you are doing something <vocabulary>for the sake of</vocabulary>. But why use fancy language like that? Let's just leave it as <vocabulary>for</vocabulary>.
You <kanji>go</kanji> for the <kanji>sake</kanji> of others. You are constantly doing <vocabulary>deed</vocabulary>s like this for others.

Things that <kanji>have</kanji> <kanji>idea</kanji>s behind them have <vocabulary>significance</vocabulary>. In other words, they're <vocabulary>significant</vocabulary>. Nothing shallow, frivolous, and thoughtless for me, thank you! I only want the significant stuff.

有意 is a formal term most commonly used in academic contexts to refer to statistically significant research results.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

<kanji>Bear</kanji> <kanji>origin</kanji> <kanji>prefecture</kanji> is <vocabulary>Kumamoto Prefecture</vocabulary>. Probably best to learn this meaning via the reading. Also, you should look up Kumamon of Kumamoto-ken.
The <kanji>earth</kanji> <kanji>prison</kanji> is a prison down inside the earth. What prison is under the earth? That would be <vocabulary>hell</vocabulary>.
If you're <kanji>inside</kanji> <kanji>prison</kanji> you're <vocabulary>in prison</vocabulary>.
When you <kanji>enter</kanji> <kanji>prison</kanji> that's <vocabulary>imprisonment</vocabulary>.

If you <kanji>exit</kanji> from <kanji>prison</kanji> you are getting your <vocabulary>release from prison</vocabulary>. But, before you move on, let me tell you one thing: Hope is a dangerous thing. Hope can drive a man insane.

You're making your <kanji>escape</kanji> from <kanji>prison</kanji> . So this means... <vocabulary>escape from prison</vocabulary>. Or <vocabulary>jailbreak</vocabulary> if you're feeling a little fancy.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>drunk</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to be drunk</vocabulary>.

This drunk feeling also happens to some people in boats and cars. But we call that <vocabulary>to be seasick</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be carsick</vocabulary>. You aren't actually drunk, but you feel like you are (and you're probably gonna puke, yuck!).
If you're <kanji>mud</kanji> <kanji>drunk</kanji>, you're so drunk you're rolling around on the ground. You are <vocabulary>dead drunk</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
A <kanji>vinegar</kanji> <kanji>thing</kanji> is a thing that has been vinegared. This is a <vocabulary>vinegared food</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>pickled food</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

The <kanji>mountain</kanji> <kanji>middle</kanji> <kanji>lake</kanji> is <vocabulary>lake Yamanaka</vocabulary>, a famous and very nice lake in Japan. It's also a lake that will help you to learn the lake kanji reading better.
<kanji>Blue</kanji> <kanji>copper</kanji> is <vocabulary>bronze</vocabulary>. Bronze gets a bluish tint to it, which is why it's a blue copper.
In a <kanji>copper</kanji> <kanji>mountain</kanji> you go in and make a <vocabulary>copper mine</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>copper</kanji> <kanji>statue</kanji> is a <vocabulary>copper statue</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
If you let someone <kanji>cut off</kanji> your <kanji>oil</kanji> supply, it's probably because of your <vocabulary>inattentiveness</vocabulary>. You <vocabulary>let your guard down</vocabulary>.
An <kanji>oil</kanji> <kanji>rice paddy</kanji> is really more like an <vocabulary>oil field</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>original</kanji> <kanji>oil</kanji> is oil in its original state. That is <vocabulary>crude oil</vocabulary>.
You take your <kanji>salary</kanji> and buy <kanji>oil</kanji>. When you are doing this, you are <vocabulary>fueling</vocabulary> something.
<kanji>Soy sauce</kanji> <kanji>oil</kanji> is <vocabulary>soy sauce</vocabulary>, or as it's called in Japanese, <vocabulary>shoyu</vocabulary>.

<kanji>Wake up</kanji> from your <kanji>bed</kanji> and get up. You are <vocabulary>rising</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>getting out of bed</vocabulary>.

起床 is a relatively formal word that is commonly used in writing. It's also used as a command to wake up individuals in settings like military bases or prisons.
Your <kanji>teardrop</kanji>s are also known as your <vocabulary>tears</vocabulary>.

The kanji and the word are the same. That means they share meanings as well. This word covers all types of <vocabulary>sword</vocabulary>s and <vocabulary>sabre</vocabulary>s, though it was originally used mostly for <vocabulary>double-edged sword</vocabulary>s.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>courage</kanji> so the verb version is what happens when you have lots of it. Someone with courage is probably the kind of person who is able <vocabulary>to be in high spirits</vocabulary> in the face of something!

勇む means <vocabulary>to be eager</vocabulary> to face something or to face it with bravery and determination. It often indicates proactive and enthusiastic engagement. You'll find it in written expressions like 喜び勇む (to joyfully and eagerly undertake something) or 勇んで出かける (to go out with determination).

You've been so busy with your <kanji>livelihood</kanji>, you didn't even notice it's started <vocabulary>to get dark</vocabulary> outside. When you're doing lots of living, days and seasons just seem <vocabulary>to end</vocabulary> rather quickly like that.

Alternatively, think about how <reading>rare</reading> (れる) it is <vocabulary>to get dark</vocabulary>. It really only happens once every 24 hours. A pretty rare occurence if you ask me.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. 

This is generally used to count single-family detached houses, but it can also be used to count individual units within a residential complex, as well as shops or restaurants.
A <kanji>white</kanji> <kanji>bear</kanji> is a <vocabulary>polar bear</vocabulary>! They're the only white bears in the whole world!
<kanji>Oil</kanji> that has <kanji>stone</kanji>s in it is from the ground. It's not olive oil, it's <vocabulary>petroleum</vocabulary>!

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>chat</kanji> or <kanji>talk</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to chat</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to talk</vocabulary>.

Your <kanji>crotch</kanji> and what's <kanji>below</kanji> it is called your <vocabulary>inseam</vocabulary>. It's that line that goes down the inside of your pants. Depending on your variety of English, you might call this your <vocabulary>inside leg</vocabulary> instead!
What exactly are your <kanji>parent</kanji> <kanji>relatives</kanji>? Your own <vocabulary>relatives</vocabulary>! You're all <vocabulary>kin</vocabulary>, after all.

auxiliary_meanings.meaning: To Be In Light Of Something

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. You learned this kanji means "model," but it can also mean "<kanji>take into account</kanji>," so the verb version means <vocabulary>to take something into account</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be in light of</vocabulary>.

鑑みる literally comes from the idea of "looking at something closely to judge it." It's a formal word used to describe the act of thoughtfully considering something based on things like prior experiences or surrounding circumstances.

It's a transitive verb, but it can take を or に to mark the thing you're taking into account. Both particles are grammatically correct, but に sounds slightly more formal, which often matches the contexts where this word is used.
A <kanji>self</kanji> <kanji>photograph</kanji> is exactly that: a <vocabulary>selfie</vocabulary>.

You see the kanji for <kanji>rain</kanji> being followed by the 天 kanji from 天気 (weather). This word means <vocabulary>rainy weather</vocabulary>.

This has a formal nuance to it, and is often used for event announcements (whether to postpone it in case of rainy weather, etc).
You've got a very <kanji>element</kanji>al <kanji>person</kanji>. They're so elementary that they're quite an <vocabulary>amateur</vocabulary>, really. Maybe a little too elemental.

If someone tells you to get <kanji>straight</kanji> to doing something, you ought to do it <vocabulary>right away</vocabulary>. Go on, chop-chop!

直ちに means to do something <vocabulary>immediately</vocabulary>, and it has a nuance of urgency — for example, a tsunami warning asking people to immediately evacuate their homes or your doctor telling you to contact them at once if you experience a certain symptom. However, it can also mean <vocabulary>directly</vocabulary>, like 失敗は直ちに死に繋がる (failure will lead directly to death).

Remember how 儲ける means "to make a profit"? Well, this is the intransitive version — the version that doesn't take a direct object — so it means <vocabulary>to be profitable</vocabulary>. The かる ending is a hint, because verbs with かる as okurigana (kana added to the kanji) are usually intransitive.

Compared to 儲ける, which is about you gaining something, 儲かる is more about the situation itself bringing in money, like この店は儲かってる (this shop is doing well). It can also refer to some benefit coming in by luck, like 一日儲かった (I got an extra day).

When something is <kanji>slight</kanji>, that means you only have <vocabulary>a few</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>a little</vocabulary> of that thing.

僅か is a relatively formal word that indicates a small amount. You'll hear it when someone wants to emphasize how little something is, like 僅かな差 (a little gap) or 僅か10分 (<vocabulary>just</vocabulary> ten minutes). Note this word is often written in kana, as わずか, unless the writing style is very formal.
